# Intro

This post is to give you an example on how to create your own polygon using google maps.


## Program

For this exercise we used the release candidate of QGIS, but every version has the option to create new layers, so no worries in which version you are using. 

```{r, echo=FALSE, fig.height=1, fig.align='center'}
Imagen1<-"https://github.com/MiriamLL/data_supporting_webpage/blob/main/Blog/2023/image1.png?raw=true"
knitr::include_graphics(Imagen1)
```

If you still dont have it, here is the link for download [QGIS](https://www.qgis.org/en/site/forusers/download.html)


## QGIS

In earlier QGIS versions, there was a plugin called **Open Layers plugin**, but is not available anymore (as far as I am aware of).

Now to add a **google satellite** map in your QGIS you could do the following:

### Go to View > Panels > Activate Browser Panel

```{r, echo=FALSE,fig.height=10,  out.width="80%"}
Imagen9<-"https://github.com/MiriamLL/data_supporting_webpage/blob/main/Blog/2023/qgis1.png?raw=true"
knitr::include_graphics(Imagen9)
```

### Now go to XYZ > a new connection

```{r, echo=FALSE, fig.height=10, out.width="50%"}
Imagen10<-"https://github.com/MiriamLL/data_supporting_webpage/blob/main/Blog/2023/qgis2.png?raw=true"
knitr::include_graphics(Imagen10)
```

### A new window will appear 

```{r, fig.height=10, echo=FALSE, out.width="60%"}
Imagen11<-"https://github.com/MiriamLL/data_supporting_webpage/blob/main/Blog/2023/qgis3.png?raw=true"
knitr::include_graphics(Imagen11)
```

### Fill in the spaces with the map you want to use

You need to give it a name and the **URL**

There are many options of maps, you can look at some here: [Google URLs](https://hatarilabs.com/ih-en/how-to-add-a-google-map-in-qgis-3-tutorial)

We will use Open Street Map: https://tile.openstreetmap.org/{z}/{x}/{y}.png for the example.

```{r, fig.height=10, echo=FALSE, out.width="80%"}
Imagen12<-"https://github.com/MiriamLL/data_supporting_webpage/blob/main/Blog/2023/qgis4.png?raw=true"
knitr::include_graphics(Imagen12)
```

Once you have create the connection, double click on the name and the map should be loaded as a layer.

```{r, fig.height=10, echo=FALSE, out.width="40%"}
Imagen14<-"https://github.com/MiriamLL/data_supporting_webpage/blob/main/Blog/2023/qgis6.png?raw=true"
knitr::include_graphics(Imagen14)
```

Ready to Use!

```{r, fig.height=10, echo=FALSE, out.width="50%"}
Imagen13<-"https://github.com/MiriamLL/data_supporting_webpage/blob/main/Blog/2023/qgis5.png?raw=true"
knitr::include_graphics(Imagen13)
```


## Create polygon

### Select New Shapefile Layer

```{r, fig.height=10, echo=FALSE, out.width="40%"}
Imagen15<-"https://github.com/MiriamLL/data_supporting_webpage/blob/main/Blog/2023/qgis7.png?raw=true"
knitr::include_graphics(Imagen15)
```

### Give a name to your new shapefile

I recommend to click on the three dots to select also the directory

In the exercise, we will create a polygon, therefore, select **Polygon** in Geometry type

```{r, fig.height=10, echo=FALSE, out.width="40%"}
Imagen16<-"https://github.com/MiriamLL/data_supporting_webpage/blob/main/Blog/2023/qgis8.png?raw=true"
knitr::include_graphics(Imagen16)
```


### Select Layer > Toggle editing, or just click on the icon with the yellow pencil

```{r, fig.height=10, echo=FALSE, out.width="20%"}
Imagen17<-"https://github.com/MiriamLL/data_supporting_webpage/blob/main/Blog/2023/qgis9.png?raw=true"
knitr::include_graphics(Imagen17)
```


### Now add polygon feature by clicking on the green polygon icon

```{r, fig.height=10, echo=FALSE, out.width="20%"}
Imagen18<-"https://github.com/MiriamLL/data_supporting_webpage/blob/main/Blog/2023/qgis10.png?raw=true"
knitr::include_graphics(Imagen18)
```

### Use the pointer of your mouse and click one time to create points

The areas will start to look red

Keep clicking until you have a more or less the polygon you want

When you finish you should add an id, here I used the number 1 for an example

```{r, fig.height=10, echo=FALSE, out.width="70%"}
Imagen20<-"https://github.com/MiriamLL/data_supporting_webpage/blob/main/Blog/2023/qgis11.png?raw=true"
knitr::include_graphics(Imagen20)
```

Now you should have a polygon!

### To edit the shapes you can use the vertex tool

```{r, fig.height=10, echo=FALSE, out.width="30%"}
Imagen21<-"https://github.com/MiriamLL/data_supporting_webpage/blob/main/Blog/2023/qgis12.png?raw=true"
knitr::include_graphics(Imagen21)
```

### The corners can be moved/dragged when the icon has been selected

```{r, fig.height=10, echo=FALSE, out.width="80%"}
Imagen22<-"https://github.com/MiriamLL/data_supporting_webpage/blob/main/Blog/2023/qgis14.png?raw=true"
knitr::include_graphics(Imagen22)
```

### New points can be created using the cross

```{r, fig.height=10, echo=FALSE, out.width="80%"}
Imagen23<-"https://github.com/MiriamLL/data_supporting_webpage/blob/main/Blog/2023/qgis15.png?raw=true"
knitr::include_graphics(Imagen23)
```

### When you are editing your layer you will have a red pencil icon, click on the yellow pencil for **finish editing**

```{r, fig.height=10, echo=FALSE, out.width="30%"}
Imagen24<-"https://github.com/MiriamLL/data_supporting_webpage/blob/main/Blog/2023/qgis16.png?raw=true"
knitr::include_graphics(Imagen24)
```

### Do not forget to save the changes!

```{r, fig.height=10, echo=FALSE, out.width="30%"}
Imagen25<-"https://github.com/MiriamLL/data_supporting_webpage/blob/main/Blog/2023/qgis18.png?raw=true"
knitr::include_graphics(Imagen25)
```

... Now you are done!

I hope this helped you.
